@jpegdigital @manifoldxyz Permissions are a big thing too, allowing an external 3rd party application, dApp, marketplace, game, or other creator have permission access to minting tokens on your creator contract unlocks some amazing use cases.

Also, a common question I've been asked is if we are using ERC-721A? The answer is no. We are leveraging the Manifold Creator extension architecture to optimize gas fees.

ERC-721A optimizes for mint costs but is more >10% expensive overall when transfers are factored in.

The gas savings are amazing, here is an example of @swolfchan minting 200 tokens using batch minting for his NiftyGatway drop.

https://t.co/5QMUqo9Nv5

@gregskril @rtfshl Revoking disallows a contract / address to act on behalf of a tokens owner.

A malicious signature could be used to grant a token authorization. Order of operations matter, but also the contents of what transaction is being signed.

@rtfshl Yes, 100% signatures can be more dangerous than approvals, you can hide anything inside a signature including a direct transfer of an NFT or a token approval.

There are good uses for signatures, but the UI and usability for signatures is probably the biggest issue.

@JKrantz It would make revoking and actually knowing what your exposure actually is traceable. I think the big thing that MetaMask needs to spend a few cycles on is usability.

I'm a developer and half the time I have to spend hours to figure out what is actually going on with MetaMask.

A common question about transaction signatures.

Q: How do I know if I've signed a bad transaction in the past?

A: You can't tell. There is no record of past signed transactions. 

MetaMask really should store a log of all signed transactions for review after the fact.

Topics so far:
â€¢ Setting up a hardware wallet
â€¢ Storing your seed phrase properly
â€¢ Common scams 
â€¢ How token approvals work
â€¢ Wallet setups (hot, cold, multi-sig)

I've been putting together step-by-step guide beginner to advanced crypto and NFT security concepts.

While twitter threads are great, I think having a resource page with a checklist that you can follow would be better.

Anyone have any topics they want to see covered?
@cmbarce1 The question is what did you sign? there are different types of signatures, hard to tell without context. It could be signing a message or signing a transaction.

@GusR511 Yes revoking helps, but that is only one attack vector. 

It's more about understanding what it means and when / how to use it.

The recent OpenSea phishing attack, shows just how fast bad, wrong, and mis-information can travel. 

Crypto security education is something that everyone needs to spend time and invest in.

You don't know what you don't know.
